title: Skinny House (Long Beach)
text:
The aptly nicknamed Skinny House at 708 Gladys Avenue (corner of 7th Street) in the <a href="Rose%20Park%2C%20Long%20Beach%2C%20California">Rose Park</a> neighborhood of <a href="Long%20Beach%2C%20California">Long Beach</a>, <a href="California">California</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, is a narrow three-story <a href="house">house</a> that has been cited by both the <a href="Guinness%20Book%20of%20World%20Records">Guinness Book of World Records</a> and <a href="Ripley%27s%20Believe%20It%20or%20Not">Ripley's Believe It or Not</a> as the nation's skinniest house.
The yellow-<a href="stucco">stucco</a>ed house was built on a lot measuring by in 1932 by Newton P. Rummonds, who received the land as a repayment for a $100 loan one year earlier. He built the house after someone bet him that he could not build a habitable house on such a small lot.
In 1959, it was discovered that the house had leaned to the north and was straightened. The Skinny House is a registered city landmark of Long Beach, California, as of 1983.
Public interest lawyer <a href="William%20John%20Cox">William John Cox</a> maintained his law practice in Skinny House between 1977 and 1981, including his prosecution of the <a href="Holocaust%20denial">Holocaust denial</a> case.
The house was featured in a segment of "<a href="The%20Early%20Show">The Early Show</a>".
